title: Investigating Recrystallization Kinetics of 316L Stainless Steel in Hybrid Manufacturing for Microstructure Control
content: Hybrid manufacturing, which seamlessly integrates additive and subtractive processes, has emerged as a transformative manufacturing technique. By combining the strengths of both techniques, it enables the production of geometrically complex components such as tools with conformal cooling channels [1] and engineering components with sensors embedded in them [2], that were unattainable with traditional approaches. Hybrid manufacturing has also been shown to reduce overall manufacturing time [3,4] compared to pure additive manufacturing followed by machining. Furthermore, it has been reported that 316L stainless steel (SS) fabricated by hybrid manufacturing has a higher elongation failure and minimal reduction of strength during tensile testing that can be compared to properties of a two-step approach for manufacturing materials. While prior research has focused on control and evolution of microstructure during additive manufacturing [5-8], our study delves into a critical aspect of hybrid manufacturing: microstructure controll through the machining component of hybrid manufacturing.
